pros: Good insurance benefits, retirement, and my boss was nice. Good amount of vacation time. Smart is a good person who really seems to care.
cons:
Significantly lower pay than most places. Literally my kid makes more working in fast food than I do working at MSU. The upper management doesn't know/understand because they have said "If our graduates are starting at $13/hr we have failed them" (Clif Smart said this in 2019) while hiring people for that and less who graduated from this school. 

You have to pay for parking even if you work here.

Some of the faculty and staff are awful with/to students. Looking at you audiology dept. If anyone at MSU reads this, you seriously need to look into this dept. They are breaking laws and abusing/harassing students.

You will not get raises.

job_title: Residence Hall Director in Springfield, MO
pros: Staff members in the Division of Student Affairs are collaborative across different functional areas. Staff are enjoyable to interact with on work-related projects and will also spend time together at local restaurants and entertainment venues. Professional development opportunities (with financial support) are available at the university, regional, and national level. Campus improvements have contributed to a more enjoyable campus feel. Health, dental, and vision benefits are very good. There are also annual funds that can be used to take non-credit fee courses and/or towards health and fitness activities (massages and personal training at the campus recreation center).
cons: Missouri State University has conversations and invites guest speakers to discuss diversity and inclusion, but the university needs to put more words into action. Unfortunately, the city/region of Springfield is not the most inclusive community for underrepresented and marginalized populations. Missouri State University should do more to be the leading voice in the region to increase awareness and inspire effective action.

review_title: LOVED the job HATED the coworkers
job_title: SOAR (Student Orientation Advisement and Registration) Leader in Springfield, MO
pros:
Meeting new students and parents, getting to know a TON about the University, become a jack of all trades. I loved the time that I was with students and getting them excited about MSU

Free meals at the dining hall and boomer meals and free housing on campus.
cons:
They preach about 'family' but treat you like they own you.

You're told that they pay for the mandatory class 2 credit class you have to take to be a SOAR leader, but they didn't. You're paying 300 bucks to trained and if you don't get a good grade (which isn't too bad, I got a B barely) it'll cause a B on your transcript.

You get minimum wage and they tell you what to log for hours. You get paid the same every week even if you worked 4 hours more doing a different job so you kinda work for free.

Unless you kiss-butt to the people in charge you are treated as if you're terrible.  "Super SOAR Bear" was a weekly 'soar leader of the week' and essentially who kissed butt the best.

As soon as you get off work you essentially live with your co workers. It becomes cliquey very fast and honestly after being with the same people from 6:46AM-11:30PM Monday-Thursday it gets old very fast.

pros: The work environment is supportive
cons: No cons that I can think of at this time

pros: People are generally nice, although deeply resistant to change
cons: Everything takes forever to get through the system.

review_title: Great place for a student to work!

cons: Sometime being a student is a disadvantage

review_title: Solid Job, but pay could be better
job_title: Administrative Specialist II in Springfield, MO
pros:
- Affordable benefits: $40 / mo for individuals, but they offer incentives that allow medical to drop to $10 a month.
- Most faculty are appreciative and supportive of your position
- Extra given days (paid days off) per the President of the university- You get 3 days off for thanksgiving and 2 weeks around Christmas. 
- Low stress most of the time
- 15 credits of free classes per year
cons:
-Staff do not get wifi outside of their work computers. So you can't log your phone to wifi or a laptop if you're on your lunch break and want to get stuff done. 
- There are not a lot of pay raises outside the standard across the board increase. There are some people who've been in the position for over ten years who make less than the median value for the position. 
- You have to pay for your own parking pass
-Public education means lots of micromanaging to follow regulations
-Some faculty can act demeaning towards office staff
-Sometimes downtime can last a whole week
-You don't get access to the recreation center

review_title: Schedule flexibility is the trade for all the bureaucracy
pros: As a student worker, the schedule is very flexible and as part of the service desk you get paid well ($9.50 at the moment)
cons: There's so much bureaucracy and red tape that if you don't just ignore it and tip toe so that you don't accidentally take a side you'll get sucked into the horrible vortex of ridiculous workplace power struggles. Also, the service desk people, who takes phone calls, chats and in-person account issues,  are only paid 40 cents more than lab assistants who sit and scroll through Imgur and occasionally help someone fix their wifi. The first two weeks of every semester is hell for both the labs and the service desk, but primarily the service desk since they get the most contact with users.

pros: There is so much potential for growth as a student working for the university.  Working for the OSE gave me the experience at a young age to figure out the skills that I can flourish in.  All of the employees working in this office are dedicated to student success.  They are constantly there to challenge, coach and provide support in all areas.  I am extremely thankful for this position during college as it has shaped my personal and professional development.  Highly recommend.
cons: This is tough, I can honestly say that I only have positive things to say of working for this university.  I guess the one thing I could say is that the pay could be better for the responsibility that you are given.

pros:
I was a student worker at the Missouri State Bookstore & they have some amazing mangers running things like customer service, clothing, and the  convenient stores. Awesome managers who understand how to lead. I would follow these mangers just about anywhere because they just understand how to motivate. It is a very relaxed atmosphere not very competitive. And saving the best for last, they work around class schedules!! 
Great college job.
cons:
Some managers are grumpy, sometimes hard to be around. 
A lot of student employees you don't to chat or meet any big dogs in the company/school.

job_title: SOFAC Student Specialist in Springfield, MO
pros:
As a student worker, I obviously needed a lot of time outside of the job to focus on my studies. My position in the Office of Student Engagement at Missouri State University gave me this flexibility. My pros are as follows:

Flexible hours
Great Work-Life Balance
Freedom to approach things in a manner you see is best 
Professional staff are great advisers and provide an abundance of guidance and wisdom
Staff is friendly and engaged
Current employees are given priority when applying for new promotions
cons:
Pay is so-so and raises are few and far between and are based on tenure at the organization instead of the quality of work produced
There are peak periods where you can feel overwhelmed which are then followed by very boring lows where there is absolutely nothing to do
Change is slow
Technology is quite old
Budget is strict

review_title: Great learning experience--wish they'd hire me full time!
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Springfield, MO
pros: If you're lucky enough to awarded a Graduate Teaching Assitantship in the English department, be prepared for an intense two years. As a teacher, you'll be closely guided by experts in the field and may be able to not only teach composition but poetry, fiction, non-fiction, or TESOL. Best two years of my life and I miss it!
cons: The pay isn't great but the tuition waiver makes it worth it. I don't have first hand experience, but have heard it can be difficult to advance in any department and the salary is considerably lower than other state universities. Springfield is a fine college town, but may not be somewhere you'd want to settle. The Queen City of the Ozarks is also in the Bible belt; something to consider if you're not a conservative Christian.

review_title: Work Study: Brick City 1 Art Shop
pros: Do not have to directly handle, cash, check, or card. Through out most of the year the shop is pretty quiet and there is plenty of time for the student employees to work on homework. The environment is quiet and slow paced employees are even allowed to listen to music quietly or surf the internet when not occupied with helping a customer or performing other duties around the shop.
cons:
The fact that the shop doesn't take cash, check, or card is a double edge sword and even though it is quick and easy if a student comes in unprepared they often get irritated and have to wait up to 15 minutes to upload money to their student pass just to purchase an item. 
Each worker works their shift by themselves without any interaction with other co-workers.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Springfield, MO
pros:
Tuition waver for graduate studies. From 2015-2017, I was allowed to take up to 15 credit hours in the fall and spring and up to 6 credit hours in the summer, paid for my the university. This job paid for my master's degree!

20 hours a week of great work experience in research. Got to work alongside faculty and build professional connections. Gained experience in different data analysis software and editing and submitting articles for publication. I was even able to work with some professors on a textbook. This job really enhanced my resume.

The professors in my department were very pleasant to work with, and I believe I'll maintain contact with them in the years to come.
cons: It was difficult to live on the annual stipend. I had to take out a student loan to supplement my expenses.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant/Masters Student in Springfield, MO
pros:
A friendly atmosphere, you almost get to know everybody on campus, great life and very low cost of living in Springfield, MO.
A great place to work if you are interested in buisiness oriented programs (MBA etc). 
A beautiful campus.......well taken care of. Lot of benifits and discounts for the employees. Administration and management are easily approachable.
cons: Lack of PhD programs.....resulting in lack of funding and adequate growth oppurtunity for graduate students. Porrly equipped labs. Not a great scope for clinical research or medical research. Most of the rating for university are recieved for business programs. Lot of funding needed to improve the standard of science departments.

job_title: User Support Specialist in Springfield, MO
pros: Missouri State University is a great employer, they had great benefits and the 2nd shift was a great shift to work. The student workers were pleasant and hard working and the Director of User Support was also a great boss and the teachers were for the most part quick to learn the technology
cons: Working projects while supporting teachers was a tighter fit for fitting into the standard work week and there was not always a even distribution of tickets across the shifts (but this is not due to the managers but other shift workers).

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Sprin, MO
pros: Relaxed place to work, supportive staff and faculty, many different ways to learn on the job, lots of benefits although limited for part time staff, and lots of protocol put in place to protect employees. MSU really cares about the whole well being of their employees and students.
cons: Budgets cuts have hurt everyone this year some of us had our positions entirely cut due to the cuts.

review_title: Great environment and opportunity for per-course teaching.
job_title: Per Course Instructor/Marketing in Springfield, MO
pros: I love teaching per-course at Missouri State's marketing department. I have support when I need it but the independence to create a class schedule and curriculum of my own. The compensation is great for per course.
cons: I wish there were more formally shared resources. My first semester was definitely the hardest, but each semester gets better and I am able to improve my teaching.

review_title: Great place to work if you can avoid the politics.
pros: Lots of opportunities for graduate students to work and pay for tuition at the same time. Graduate assistantships are challenging and provide a lot of good opportunities to network for someone hoping to make a career on a college campus.
cons: There are a lot of politics involved with being a graduate assistant at Missouri State, especially if you find yourself working in the corporate office or one of the academic departments. People sometimes have a hard time minding their own business and the gossip chain can be unsettling.

review_title: Graduate Assistantship is the road to education AND experience
pros: MSU had provided such a great opportunity to graduates with an interest in working in the university setting. Being a GA brings opportunities for a diverse work experience and additional study. Management, at least within my departments, has been exemplary and helpful throughout this process.
cons: As great as the university is, the city (Springfield, MO) might lack a good deal of essential amenities for those accustomed to living in larger cities.

review_title: Great learning experience as a Graduate Teaching Assistant in the English Department.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant/Masters Student in Springfield, MO
pros: The English department has incredible faculty that guide you through your two years of teaching. The office atmosphere with the other teaching assistants can't really be rivaled, especially with the friendships that develop as well as the professional development opportunities.
cons: Even though the pay for this position includes a tuition waiver, the salary was barely enough to get by. It was also hard to balance teaching responsibilities (grading, teaching, conferences) with my own class responsibilities.

pros: There was a lot of experience gained for a student to start working in the field early on. It gives great feedback to students to grow their skillset and experience.
cons: A downside to the office is the limited budget for students, it can be difficult to juggle multiple jobs, classes and the various tasks you'll be in charge of because of the limited hours available and minimum pay.

pros: Faculty and staff have a lot of days off, development options, and opportunities to get involved are around every corner.
cons: The pay is sub-par. They expect people to stick around because of school spirit despite the poor pay. The politics and hierarchies make it fairly difficult for people to move up without waiting in line. Mediocrity is rewarded.

review_title: Graduate Assistantship is the way to make it through Grad College
pros: MSU is a great place to study and education level is high and constructive. Being a GA allowed me to pay for my school while making some money. I gain a lot of experiences and interacted with several people. MSU is very international so you might see a lot of Asians and people from many other countries of the world.
cons: Perhaps it was not a good career path after finishing being a GA with 2 masters. The addition of being an  international student makes it a little harder but no impossible. You gotta keep trying and applying.

pros: Missouri State University is a public, comprehensive university system with a mission in public affairs. Our purpose is to develop fully educated persons with a focus on ethical leadership, cultural competence and community engagement.
cons:
More than 24,000 students in the Missouri State system making it the second largest university in the state
Six academic colleges, one School of Agriculture and one Graduate College
Almost 4,000 faculty and staff members with 90 percent of full-time ranked faculty holding the most advanced degree in their field

review_title: MSU really is a great place to work
job_title: Warehouse and Delivery Clerk in Springfield, MO
pros: Although the pay is on the lower end for staff, the benefits are top notch. Medical and dental insurance, retirement, plenty of time off, and free tuition (to an extent). Overall, these factors make it a great place to work.
cons: The only downside is that the pay isn't all that great for regular staff, but there's more than enough benefits to make up for that.

pros: Lots of perks-extensive amount of vacation, time off between Christmas and New Years that you are off but don't apply to your vacation time. Health clinic on campus. A sense of community and energy. Tuition credit.
cons: Compensation is low. Can be political at times with office drama that is allowed to fester. It kind of depends on the department, though.

review_title: My Alma Mater....But That's About It
pros:
•Competitive health benefits
•Generous holiday breaks
•Vested
cons:
•Morale among staff is at an all-time low.  Average staff member is there for @ 3.5 years.
•Faculty are revered; staff are virtually invisible.
•People leave + Hiring freeze due to "budget cuts" = More work for everyone else!

review_title: Great place to get a masters
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Springfield, MO
pros: light workload, great pay compared to a lot of schools, you get paid at the end of May, if you get a summer appointment it is more than the normal monthly pay
cons: sometimes workload is inconsistent, summer pay isn't guaranteed, we don't get paid in August so our first pay check isn't until Sept 30, we only get paid once a month (at the end of the month)

job_title: Student Web Developer in Springfield, MO
pros:
AMAZING learning environment.
Worked on cutting edge projects.
Worked with a couple of very knowledgeable staff.
Extremely helpful bosses.
You can ride the shuttle to work from campus.
Flexible hours.
Flexible time off for school.
cons:
Occasionally had to field CMS help desk calls.
Pay was below average for the work.
Some of the other student works are sub par performers.
Those are the only two negatives I can remember.

review_title: Mediocre institution with a few rare gems.
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Springfield, MO
pros: The overall structure of MSU is pretty standard and straightforward.
cons: The department I teach in is disorganized, under-funded, and full of drama. Though I am a graduate student working as a teaching assistant, I have had little to no support beyond being given the title of the class I am to teach and the room number. I know this is not the case in other departments, but having spoken at length with tenured faculty, the dysfunction in this department is pervasive and ongoing.

review_title: Easy work, difficult to work with department head
job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in Springfield, MO
pros: Really east work, flexible hours make it good for college students to work when they can. Sense of accomplishment when helping out.
cons: The new management that has taken over really change the whole culture of the job... for the worse. Went from lax to really strict, when it isn't needed to be

pros:
Getting to work by yourself and complete homework in between shop duties and customers. y boss even let me listen to music on the computer as long as it was at a reasonable volume.
The shop is nice and small and able to easily be handled by one person.
cons: Even though it is nice to work by yourself during a shift it makes it difficult to communicate and relay information about the shop, a product, or a customer to other coworkers.

pros: Well-meaning administration, good benefits, economical housing.
cons: Culturally and intellectually, Springfield is something of a backwater. (Try reading the local paper and watching the local news for a week.) I and many other faculty became increasingly frustrated with student apathy and limited learning over the last 10 years, but concerns along these lines expressed to the administration fell on deaf ears. As long as enrollments are high, the administration sees no reason to strive to transform the academic culture.

pros: Economics department is a great overall place to work at the university.  Very flexible and friendly, except for secretary.  Department head is fantastic!!
cons: Certain people within the department are not nice at all.  There tends to be a lot of office politics and bitterness, but only with select individuals.

review_title: Its been a challange to keep this job as the management changes every few years as do basic rules.
pros: The benefits are very good free health insurance .
cons: Work hours are bad 4A.M. to 12:30 PM, Management changes  often and so do the rules , one monnth you lock doors next month leave unsecured its a bit crazy.

pros: Good place to work.  Don't have the headaches of the corporate world.  Good perks and benefits to being a state employee.
cons: Make everyone pull their weight and don't let personal feelings influence work decisions. Give some raises to someone besides athletic coaches once in awhile.

review_title: Good seasonal job for a student
pros: Relative flexible work hours at the beginning of each semester, nice staff to work with, and get to help new students to settle down while making some money.
cons: The air port pick ups can be a bit tedious when it requires late night hours. It also involves some physical strength for hauling new students luggage.

review_title: I learned a lot of practical skills working as student web developer.
job_title: Student Web Developer in Springfield, MO
pros: My hours within my office were very flexible, I choose what hours I worked on each day. They really let me work around my school schedule.
cons: Because of a student policy I was only allowed to work 20 hours a week during the school year, and under 40 during breaks and summer. 20 hours a week was hard to live on.

pros: Outstanding support from upper level management (Dean of the Graduate Office), work-life balance (flexible and adjustable schedule in accord to your needs), training and development opportunities (learning process throughout 2 years with the bests), and the opportunity of meeting brilliant individuals (faculty and students).
cons: There were not cons in particular. However, having some type of health benefits would help.

pros: Wonderful place to learn and grow with the freedom to work on projects your interested in. Great place to learn as IT, Software Developer or Graphics Design.
cons: Coworkers are sometimes under qualified or uninterested with only the desire to be there and get paid contributing an absolute minimum.

review_title: Great part time job while working through college
pros: Very flexible hours, they work well about your classes, off work by 5 every day, get to meet people you see around campus
cons: It can be hard work, I didn't always love the people I worked with.

pros: Good lower management working directly above you.  Really flexible and overall good managers.  Compensation was really good, gave academics priority.
cons: Awful upper management.  The Res Life system is terrible here.  They have the lowest retention rate with ra's for a reason.

review_title: It depends on the building,area and department you are hired in. some jobs are laid back perfect. others are a hell on e
pros: the retirement (mosers) is good.
cons: hot buildings, not so bright co-workers

pros:
Paid holidays and, occasional, weather-related closings.
Free classes to employee or transferrable to immediate family members.
On-site, full service health center with pharmacy and professional consultants at Springfield campus.
Internal transfers for additional opportunities and advancement.
Discounted event tickets when available.
cons:
Parking fees although, from what I understand, reasonable compared to other universities.
Parking spaces can be limited early in the fall semester; however, shuttles are readily available.

review_title: Small university feel at a rapidly-growing campus
pros: Missouri State is an inviting community.  I enjoy working with many of my colleagues and many are very friendly and helpful to work with / for.
cons: The administration seems resistant to major changes.  The University is still growing into the Missouri State name change and with that comes some major shifts in culture, operations, and leadership.

job_title: Front Desk Receptionist in Springfield, MO
pros: Staff are very friendly, pay is reasonable
cons: Forget trying to find a parking space. There is not enough parking available for the amount of staff and students on campus every day. on top of that, you have to purchase a parking permit.

review_title: MSU Makes you feel at home
job_title: Health Center Worker in Springfield, MO
pros: The people at the university are great, whether it's in your department or departments you work directly with everyone seems pleased to be there.  The benefits are also incredible
cons: It's a state funded university so there is some of that "red tape" feel to the way things have to be done.

review_title: Too Many Old Guard, Too Little Concern for Students
pros: Students are often times the 1st of their families to attend college.  They take their studies seriously.
cons: Out dated mindsets on the part of faculty and staff.

pros: you will be experienced in public relationship, customer service, and of course with technology.
cons: Lot of works and not enough salary. Sometimes management can be careless too.

pros: There is no better place to pursue a graduate assistantship than Missouri State. Tuition waivers plus monthly stipend. Flexible schedules, great people.
cons: You are tied to a one- or two-year position that may or may not relate to your degree.  In most positions you can make great connections, though.

review_title: Great Opportunity for Part-time Student Development
pros:
Autonomy
Advisement
Clear Goals and Mission
Friendly Environment
Managers see student workers as equals with valuable ideas and contributions
cons:
Pay isn't great
Jobs are competitive
No real room for professional growth as a student worker

pros: Learned teaching strategies with my mentor and learned how to deal with international students from various cultures.
cons: Did not have many teaching opportunities.

pros: it's a good place to work, it is reasonably safe and there's lots of campus development going on to make it look more attractive.
cons: the city of springfield is not an easy place to live in if you're a minority.

pros: Great place to work. Diverse student population, administrative support for the staff, opportunities to develop teaching protocol.
cons: It's a small university campus. Some classes do not have enough attendance and will be cancelled limiting your teaching opportunities.You must submit an application each semester to teach a class (new requirement).

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Springfield, MO
pros: Great environment... supportive people, Good place to work and grow.
cons: Pay, Missouri State is lagging behind in this area, but then again... all schools are cutting and tightening their belts

review_title: TIP:  fully consider reviews before accepting an offer
pros: flexibility and benefits are top benefits
cons: unethical leadership and hiring practices, lack of support in job function, low pay

pros: Great perks like lots of paid holidays and time off. The Health coverage is completely covered and there is an on-sight clinic available on the Springfield campus.
cons: Little chance of upward movement and professional development at least in my department.  Not much in the way of wage raises.

pros: Great benefits, lots of vacation options plus public holidays, great health insurance benefits
cons: No room for growth or advancement, raises are across the board so doesnt matter how hard you work, everyone gets a raise. most people come here for health benefits and vacation benefits.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Springfield, MO
pros: The financial compensation for working as a GA is very generous in comparison to other universities. My supervisor genuinely valued me as an employee and was flexible with my fluctuating schedule as a student.
cons: Working as a GA can be challenging with a rigorous academic program.

pros: Good vacation package.  Nice offices (if you like being stuck indoors).  Education opportunities if you can find classes that don't take place during your work hours.
cons: Politics, politics, politics.  Meetings, meetings, meetings.  Then more politics.  Constantly changing the programming languages being used.  Multiple languages/technologies used in nearly each system.  Very little programming standards.  Unless you know someone you have to park and walk 15-20 minutes to get to work.

review_title: A technical pedagogue right next to class
job_title: Student Web Developer in Springfield, MO
pros: Great experience, good starter development position, multifaceted environment, flexible schedule
cons: Part-time student pay, small work space

pros: Flexible around your class and homework schedule. If you live on campus or near the bearline your commute is free and relatively easy.
cons: Pay is terrible. 7 or 8 dollars an hour max

pros: Holidays, vacation and sick time accrual, and less stressful than corporate world.
cons: Very low starting salaries, well below industry averages and no raises for 7 years.

pros: You can set your own hours, very flexible.  You are able to work on school work if you are not busy.
cons: They give you a stipend every month, which is great, but it can be pretty tough to make the amount last over the entire month.

review_title: It is very nice to work there, but poor pay.
job_title: Web Works Student Developer in Springfield, MO
pros: It is excellent working experience and I have learned a lot working there.
cons:
Paid in beans.

Cannot work on homework on the job like is possible at other student employment positions on campus.

pros: MSU cares about its employees.   The jobs are secure and the community is accepting.
cons: Budget cuts across the state affect all higher institutions of education.  MSU tries to balance the needs of the students with the needs of the faculty.

job_title: Senior Student Help Desk Analyst in Springfield, MO
pros: Employees are reliable and honestly care about doing a great job in what they do. Structure of the Computer Services department was overall fairly flat and easily maneuvered.
cons: Reasonable pay for salaried employees, not particularly good for student workers trying to scrape by.

review_title: It was a great work environment especially because I worked with people I went to school with.
pros: The team I worked with motivated me to work hard. There were many growth opportunities.
cons: I really liked working there a lot.

review_title: Supportive office, campus not so much
pros: Learned a lot, especially about how politics can affect what your office gets. The students are absolutely the highlight.
cons: Salary is pretty much as low as they can get away with, honestly. There are plenty of better paying institutions out there.

review_title: Gives you a good chance of getting TA if you are a grad student in a STEM field
job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Springfield, MO
pros: Gives you a good chance of getting TA if you are a grad student in a STEM field
cons: Lots of homeworks and projects as a grad student

job_title: Assistant Hall Director in Springfield, MO
pros:
-Great co-workers
-Grad experience solid
-High levels of autonomy with certain responsibilities
-Impactful position with the student body
cons:
-Toxic upper management
-High levels of micromanagement with certain responsibilities
-The leadership team has a poor work-life balance, which trickles down to professional staff

pros: Great benefits and time off.
cons: No forward movement on strategy in certain key departments.  Wages are 25% below comparable positions.

job_title: Web Works Student Developer in Springfield, MO
pros: Flexible schedule, Excellent work environment, Chance to work on a variety of projects in a variety of different languages.
cons: There is a lot of busy-work involved for software devs primarily related to CSS styling of individual pages or work on Webpress.

pros: it's a great opportunity for the students of materials science dept to work with such highly qualified professors. They are dedicated to teach us.
cons: It takes time to get chemicals or gas, sometimes the service guy comes too late

pros: Easy-going work environment, convenient on-campus job, (mostly) kind staff, flexible schedule around classes etc., can sometimes do homework during shifts if slow.
cons: Low pay compared to competing jobs, sometimes full time staff is sort of sassy to the students.

review_title: This is a review for the school bookstore not for Missouri State University
pros: there are employee discounts for students. 30% off bear wear, 15% for gift souvenirs
cons: The front desk was sometimes rowdy at certain times of the day, due to over scheduling.

job_title: Architect Project Manager in Springfield, MO
pros: Benefits are excellent and provide for good quality of living. (Many holidays, retirement benefits, insurance, limited overtime - basically a 40-45 hour job!!)
cons: Pay is below market rate. Negotiating the internal politics. Not a job for every one.

pros: Health insurance is great. Vacation time and extra days off are exceptional.
cons: Pay is below average for Springfield. Management is quite political.

pros: money, experience, bosses, and on campus
cons: no homework, and bad hours sometimes

job_title: Project Architect/Project Manager in Springfield, MO
pros: Being in a position to make a real difference in the built environment at a large scale that impacts the learning environment for 10's of thousands.
cons: The excssivee amount of Bureaucracy, Internal Politics, and pay

review_title: Grad Assistant At Missouri State University
pros:
Flexibility in hours
Understanding that you are a student first
Co-workers are super friendly
cons:
Pay could be better
No insurance

job_title: Box Office Manager in Springfield, MO
pros: Works around your class schedule, while eliminating the need for transportation to and from work. Also provided good pay for the work that was needing to be completed
cons: I did not experience any cons.

pros: Great benefits including paid time off and educational opportunities.
cons: Poor management - just because somebody has a doctorate in their field, doesn't necessarily mean they know how to supervise an office. No career development/advancement opportunity.

pros: Extremely flexible hours, graduate school is paid for
cons: Sometimes the definition of your job is stretched

pros: Awesome flexibilty, understanding of class schedules, overall a positive work environment.
cons: Not a whole lot of cons, of course pay could always be better but for the benefits and flexibility you can't go wrong.

review_title: I work as an administrative assistant to the office and faculty.
pros: Good pay, pays for grad school, convenient,  close to school and home,
cons: not necessarily the career field I want to go into.

pros: Provides tuition waiver; Provides a stipend; Provides an opportunity to gain professional experience in your field while pursuing your degree
cons: Limited to parttime employment/wages; difficult to find work/life balance with job/night classes/school work

job_title: Brick City Lab Monitor in Springfield, MO
pros:
Could choose my own schedule
Didn't have to work many hours
cons:
Minimum wage with no way of raising that
The amount of hours I could work were dependent on the department's budget

pros: Very friendly peers, and the students are great
cons: Cost of living is very low in Springfield, so salaries tend to be a bit lower as well. Compared to other universities.

pros: Good working environment, good people and facilities
cons: Low research focus, no doctorate degree program.

job_title: Computer Lab Assistant in Springfield, MO
pros: I was able to work on homework in my downtime. The people that work there are great.
cons: Sometimes I would work early mornings, but you can choose your shift times.

job_title: Web Programmer Analyst/Server Administrator in Springfield, MO
pros: Great benefits. Healthcare plan is unbeatable. Tons of vacation & sick days. Mostly laid back work environment.
cons: Grossly underpaid compared to similar/lesser jobs in the surrounding area.

pros:
Professional, campus, courteous
Access to extracurricular activities, i.e. basketball

limited social interaction
limited interaction with other colleges & departments

job_title: Sign Shop Technician in Springfield, MO
pros: Scheduling flexibility, friendly staff, on-campus, real-life experiences in industry, good class-work-social balance
cons: Minimum wage, max of 20 hours a week

pros: Great benefits: medical, dental, vacation time, etc.
cons: In my experience of 11 years, there hasn’t been much room for growth and moving to a higher position within my department.

pros:
I worked with a great group individuals
very challenging

can be VERY time consuming (you work 24/7)
upper management don't communicate with each other well

review_title: A Great Working Experience as an Tutor
pros: Work with clients. Enhance professional knowledge and skills.
cons: Hourly rate was low. Income was depend on how many clients you have

pros: Best company to work for in most positions. Pay isn't great, but benefits and the friendships you make are amazing.
cons: Not the best pay in the world..

job_title: Artist In Residence in Springfield, MO
pros: Great student and work environment. There is positive shifts
cons: Very few people of color in both the faculty and staff positions and student body population

review_title: Great learning community, supportive colleagues, lots of room for personal development
pros: Friendly and supportive culture among colleagues
cons: Benefits are not so good, especially healthcare

pros: Stress free atmosphere  for students
cons: Needs more infrastructure and addition of more course work

review_title: Good college to start, physics department is open and supportive
pros: good colleagues both fellow students and professors
cons: smaller budget means less research opportunities that pay the bills.

pros: Very flexible schedule. Very professional employers
cons: I could not found any cons. Everything is perfect

pros: Great atmosphere, and great place to work. -Receive a stipend, and get your school paid for.

review_title: Very unorganized, and trying to be too many things instead of choosing a focus

review_title: Great way to pay for your education
pros: Free tuition, great work life balance, friendly people
cons: No cons really, pay is near market and everyone is friendly.

pros: School environment, set own schedule, good experience for future.
cons: Only ten hours a week. Sometimes there is little to do, others deadlines loom.

pros: I love my students. My coworkers are professional and supportive. The work environment is comfortable and encouraging.

pros: Nice people and a beautiful campus
cons: There aren't really any cons that I can think of

pros: Love it.  Great place to work, friendly fun atmosphere.  Very happy here.

pros: Fantastic people to work with, decent pay for what the job entails, very flexible with my schedule.

job_title: Front Desk Worker in Springfield, MO
pros: Great supervisors, but there were some miscommunications between buildings on how desks are operated.
cons: Grab hours are difficult to manage, but always available.

review_title: Being a grad assistant is great
pros: Graduate School is paid for. Flexible schedule
cons: Only get paid 8 to 10 months out of the year.

pros: I worked for MSU for 8 years.  Great place to work

pros: Could work on my own homework in my off time.
